I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  for  the  Precautionary  Financing  Facility.1 The  development  policy 
letter  confirming  the  Government  of  Indonesia’s  commitment  to  maintain  macroeconomic 
stability and implement measures to cope with the global economic slowdown and heightened 
uncertainties is in Appendix 3. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Government of Indonesia Request for Precautionary Financing Facility 

ADB’s  Precautionary  Financing  Facility. Like many other economies, the Indonesian 
2. 
economy has been affected by the deterioration in the global economic outlook and turbulence 
in the financial markets. Learning from lessons from the 1997–1998 Asian crisis and the 2008–
2009  global  financial  crisis,  the  government  has  introduced  various  measures  to  safeguard 
against  any  major  trade  and  financial  impacts  emanating  from  the  current  global  economic 
situation.  The  proposed  $500  million  facility  (a  countercyclical  support  facility  [CSF]  with  a 
precautionary  financing  option)  will  bolster  the  government’s  preparedness  to  cushion  the 
impact of higher volatility in the financial market, given the government’s increased dependence 
on the market to finance its budget requirements.  The government has met the access criteria 
for a CSF: (i) continued good macroeconomic management; (ii) potentially significant economic 
impact  (resulting  in  this  case  from  a  possible  worsening  in  the  eurozone  crisis  and  the  global 
economic slowdown); and (iii) implementation of a countercyclical program in the revised 2012 
budget (Appendix 4).2 
 
3. 
Contingent  financing  approach.  The  facility  will  be  part  of  a  $5.0  billion–$5.5  billion 
contingent financing package provided by ADB, the Government of Japan, the Government of 
Australia,  and  the  World  Bank.  The  Government  of  Indonesia  is  committed  to  first  meeting  its 
financing  needs  from  market  sources  and  will  back  up  its  intention  with  confidence-boosting 
policy measures. It will use the facility as an insurance device and fallback option to be utilized 
only  if  market  stabilization  operation,  utilization  of  alternative  debt  financing  sources,  and 
utilization of accumulative surplus cash are unable to fulfill the financing need.3 The government 
believes that the announcement of this support package would send a strong positive signal to 
the  markets,  making  it  more  likely  that  Indonesia  would  meet  its  financing  needs  in  2012  and 
2013 from market sources. 
 
B. 

Global Economic Turbulence and Indonesia Context 

4. 
Impacts of the eurozone crisis. The eurozone crisis, which intensified after September 
2011, and the global economic slowdown continue to present risks to the Indonesian economy 
through two main channels: trade and finance. 

(i) 

Trade channel. After expanding by 37% (year on year) in January–August 2011, 
the country’s export growth declined in September–December 2011 following the 
Indonesia’s  diversified  export  destination  and 
eurozone  crisis.  Despite 
commodity composition, export growth ended up much lower at 27.5% for 2011. 
Overall, net exports still contributed 1.5 percentage points to the country’s 6.5%

(ii) 

economic growth in 2011. Preliminary data for 2012 point to a further decline in 
export  growth:  year-on-year  growth  for  the  first  quarter  of  2012  decreased  to 
5.1%,  from  30.8%  in  the  same  period  in  2011.  This  suggests  that  the  dynamic 
support received from external demand in 2011 before the eurozone crisis will be 
absent in 2012 and possibly the year after. 
Financial  channel. Indonesia has been more vulnerable to volatility in financial 
markets because of its relatively open capital account and the significant foreign 
presence  in  its  stock  and  bond  markets.  At  the  same  time,  the  domestic  bond 
market  is  still  very  shallow  at  13.4%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  2011 
(34.8% in the Philippines and 67.5% in Thailand). As a result, government bond 
yields are relatively more volatile than in other countries in East Asia. In February 
2011,  the  yield  of  the  5-year  rupiah  bond  rose  to  8.5%  due  to  negative  market 
sentiment related to the eurozone crisis and expectations of accelerated inflation 
driven  by  soaring  food  prices.  During  September–November  2011,  the  Jakarta 
Stock  Exchange  composite  index  experienced  a  massive  correction  of  about 
15%. Nonresident investor holdings of rupiah-denominated tradable government 
securities  fell  from  $29.3  billion  in  July  to  $23.4  billion  at  the  end  of  November 
2011. Reflecting significant capital outflows from government securities and other 
portfolios,  the  balance  of  payments  turned  into  a  deficit  in  the  second  half  of 
2011,  and  the  country’s  gross  international  reserves  dropped  by  $14.5  billion, 
from $124.6 billion in August 2011 to $110.1 billion in December 2011.

6.  
In its April 2012 Asian Development Outlook, ADB suggests that uncertainties from the 
eurozone  remain.  While  the  risk  of  a  European  liquidity  crisis  has  diminished,  fiscal  austerity 
across the eurozone could slow economic growth. If the global economic situation worsens, the 
likely impacts include weaker export demand, more volatility of capital flows, and less availability 
of  trade  finance.  Policy  responses  should  include  switching  to  social  and  infrastructure 
spending, expanding expenditures while boosting revenues, and combating rising inequality. 
 
7. 
2012 can be summarized in the following three scenarios.4 

The potential impacts of the eurozone's economic turmoil on the Indonesian economy in

Mild  baseline  scenario.  The  sovereign  debt  crisis  in  Europe  will  be  resolved 
gradually  and  the  economic  recession  in  some  countries  in  the  eurozone  will 
remain  mild,  with  limited  second-round  impacts  on  Indonesia’s  main  trading 
partners. As efforts are made to diversify export destinations, Indonesia’s exports 
will  weaken  only  moderately.  At  the  same  time,  the  government  will  introduce 
measures to stimulate domestic demand through both fiscal and monetary policy 
to  compensate

Slower  growth  scenario.  The  uncertainty  over  the  ultimate  resolution  of  the 
lingering sovereign debt crisis in Europe and related austerity measures remains 
and the economic recession in some countries in the eurozone will deepen, with 
more  pronounced  second-round  impacts  on  Indonesia’s  main  trading  partners. 
Under this scenario, with a more significant decline in exports, economic growth 
in  Indonesia  could  miss  the  government's  target  by  about  1  percentage  point. 
The impact of this external development on the domestic financial market will be 
limited  to  a  brief  volatility  and  temporary  correction  without  disrupting  the 
government’s access to market financing. 
Crisis  scenario. The economic recession in some countries in Europe will turn 
into  a  wider  and  deeper  crisis  that  affects  more  European  core  countries  and 
other developed nations outside the eurozone. Similar to 2008, the crisis will not 
only  weaken  international  trade  substantially,  but  will  also  severely  affect  the 
financial  markets  in  developed  and  emerging  economies.  Under  this  scenario, 
economic growth in Indonesia could miss the government's target by more than 
1.5  percentage  points.  More  importantly,  the  impact  of  the  global  crisis  on 
financial  markets  would  also  be  significant,  affecting  domestic 
domestic 
confidence and disrupting the government’s access to budget financing through 
possible capital outflows and increased borrowing spreads. Under this scenario, 
without  the  contingent  financing  package,  spending  on  priority  sectors  such  as 
infrastructure  and  education  would  be  negatively  affected.  An  economic 
slowdown  of  more  than  1.5%  would  have  a  serious  impact  on  unemployment, 
potentially  affecting  0.8  million  people.  In  addition,  the  quality  of  employment 
would be reduced as up to 4 million of the labor force could move to the informal 
sector, as experienced in the 2008–2009 global financial crisis. 

 
8. 
Lessons  from  earlier  ADB  countercyclical  support  and  development  partner 
coordination. The ADB Independent Evaluation Department’s 5special evaluation study for the

implementation  of  ADB’s  past  CSFs  in  five  countries,  including  Indonesia,  recommended  the 
introduction  of  a  precautionary  financing  option  as  a  facility  variant.  These  recommendations 
have  now  been  reflected  under  the  existing  policy  for  policy-based  lending. 6 Therefore,  the 
government’s  request  represents  an  opportunity  for  ADB  to  utilize  this  innovative  modality  to 
meet the needs of a middle-income developing member country like Indonesia. The facility is an 
outcome of ADB policy dialogue with the government in coordination with development partners 
on crisis monitoring, crisis management protocol, and other related reforms.7 
 
C. 

Macroeconomic Management 

9. 
Swift  response  and  proactive  measures. The government’s response to the risks of 
the  eurozone  crisis  was  swift  and  involved  various  proactive  measures  aimed  at  maintaining 
confidence in the domestic finance sector. To anticipate the potential risks associated with large 
capital  inflows  into  government  rupiah  securities,  in  mid-2011  the  government  introduced  the 
bond  stabilization  framework.  The  framework  includes  actions  to  stabilize  the  domestic  bond 
market  in  case  of  market  turbulence,  such  as a  buyback  mechanism  in  the  secondary  market 
using  funds  from  the  state  budget;  fund-pooling  by  state-owned  enterprises;  and  utilizing  the 
accumulated  budget  surplus.  The  government  also  updated  its  crisis  management  protocol, 
specifying  appropriate  responses  at  different  levels  of  crisis  for  Bank  Indonesia,  Ministry  of 
Finance (Directorate General of Debt Management Office), and Badan Pengawas Pasar Modal 
dan Lembaga Keuangan (Capital Market Supervisory Agency). 

Indonesia  (Bank 

for  Sertifikat  Bank 

10. 
Bank  Indonesia  also  implemented  macroprudential  measures  to  reduce  short-term  and 
speculative  capital  inflows  and  mitigate  the  risks  of  sudden  reversals.  These  measures  are 
Indonesia 
introducing  a  minimum  holding  period 
certificates),  reinstating  limits  on  short-term  offshore  borrowing  of  commercial  banks  to  a 
maximum  of  30%  of  capital,  and  increasing  banks’  foreign  currency  reserve  requirements.  In 
March 2012, to reduce currency speculation, Bank Indonesia also issued a regulation requiring 
evidence  of  an  underlying  real-sector  transaction  for  foreign  currency  transactions  above 
$100,000.  Bank  Indonesia  also  tightened  lending  standards  for  motor  vehicle  financing  by 
raising the down-payment requirement. After the inflation downward trend firmed in the second 
half of 2011, Bank Indonesia started an easing cycle in October 2011 by cutting its policy rate 
by 100 basis points (bps) through February 2012. The cuts were also taken to frontload some 
adjustment measures in response to the expected global economic slowdown. 
 
11. 
Recent  macroeconomic  developments.  The  country’s  macroeconomic  condition  has 
remained  sound  despite  the  global  economic  slowdown.  The  mix  of  policy  responses  has 
proven effective so far. The financial market stabilized quickly from the turbulence resulting from 
the eurozone crisis in September 2011. Despite declining nonresident holdings of local-currency 
government securities in the August–November 2011 period, the yields of 5-year rupiah bonds 
were  down  by  about  115  bps  in  2011.  After  recovering  further  in  January─March  2012,  the 
yields  were  under  pressure  in  May  due  to  declining  nonresident  investor  holdings  of  rupiah 
denominated tradable government bonds, reflecting heightened uncertainty in the eurozone and 
weaker global economic prospects. The rupiah also depreciated by about 3.5% in May. 
 
12. 
GDP growth edged up to 6.5% year on year in 2011, from 6.2% in 2010, supported by 
sustained private consumption, stronger investment, and expanding net exports. GDP growth in 
the first quarter of 2012 weakened to 6.3% due to lower export growth. Consumer confidence 
has  also  declined  since  February  over  weakening  income  expectations.  Year-on-year  inflation

rates fell from 7.0% in late 2010 to 3.8% at the end of 2011, as food price inflation decelerated 
sharply  from  15.6%  to  3.6%.  The  deceleration  trend  was  reversed  in  March  and  the  year-on-
year  inflation  rate  edged  up  to  4.5%  in  April.  This  is  attributed  to  increased  inflationary 
expectation associated with the government’s earlier plan to increase fuel prices. 
 
13. 
The actual budget deficit for 2011 was 1.2% of GDP, again lower than the government’s 
target  of  2.1%.  The  lower-than-budgeted  deficit  resulted  from  a  combination  of  better  revenue 
performance  and  lower  capital  expenditures,  offsetting  higher  spending  on  energy  subsidies. 
Tax  revenue  collection  was  up  by  0.7%  of  GDP,  achieved  through  widening  the  tax  net  and 
improving  tax  administration.  As  a  result,  the  tax-to-GDP  ratio  edged  up  to  11.8%  of  GDP  in 
2011,  from  11.2%  in  2010.  On  the  expenditure  side,  under-disbursement  in  capital  spending 
continued in 2011, although the outcome was slightly better than in 2010. However, higher-than-
expected  oil  prices  boosted  spending  for  fuel  and  electricity  subsidies  to  3.4%  of  GDP,  from 
2.2% in 2010. With a lower deficit, the debt-to-GDP ratio of the government fell further to 25% in 
2011, maintaining its down trend. 
 
The  country’s  external  position  improved  after  the  economic  turbulence  in  September 
14. 
and October 2011. After recording a large surplus in the first half of 2011, the capital account 
turned  into  deficit  in  the  second  half  of  the  year,  reflecting  increased  portfolio  capital  outflows 
driven  by  the  prolonged  uncertainties  in  the  eurozone.  Consequently,  net  portfolio  investment 
plunged by 68.2% to $4.2 billion in 2011. However, foreign direct investment (FDI) rose strongly 
by 31.9% to a record level of $18.2 billion, in line with increased investor interest in Indonesia’s 
burgeoning consumer demand. While the current account surplus fell further (to 0.2% of GDP), 
the  balance-of-payments  surplus  remained  large  at  $11.9 billion  due  to  strong  FDI  inflows.  At 
the  end  of  2011,  the  gross  international  reserves  increased  by  $13.9  billion  to  $110.1  billion. 
Despite  weakening  export  performance  in  January-April  2012,  gross  international  reserves 
increased to $116.4 billion (6.4 months of imports and government debt payments). 
 
Reflecting  the  country’s  strong  macroeconomic  performance  and  resilience,  rating 
15. 
agencies  upgraded  Indonesia  to  investment  grade.  Fitch  Ratings  upgraded  Indonesia’s 
sovereign credit rating to BBB– on December 15, 2011; Moody’s followed suit on January 18, 
2012 (Baa3). The upgrades are expected to boost the flow of long-term capital into the country. 
 
16. 
Debt sustainability. Indonesia’s debt-to-GDP ratio has fallen steadily since 2001, even 
against the backdrop of the 2008–2009 global financial crisis. The government’s countercyclical 
spending program is not expected to adversely affect debt sustainability as a large proportion of 
the 2012 budget stimulus is devoted to additional infrastructure spending, which will improve the 
capacity  of  the  economy  to  keep  growing  in  the  medium  term.  Even  with  a  10%  increase  in 
government  debt  liability  in  2012,  the  debt  ratio  is  projected  to  return  to  the  current  level  by 
2016.8 
 
D. 
 
17. 
Infrastructure  and  social  spending.  In  light  of  the  continued  uncertain  outlook  in  the 
international  economic  environment  (oil  price  volatility,  a  fragile  recovery  in  the  United  States, 
eurozone  economic  concerns,  and  slowing  growth  in  emerging  economies),  the  2012  budget 
includes  provisions  to  give  the  government  more  flexibility  in  managing  and  mitigating  risks 
emanating  from  a  more  volatile  external  environment.  The  2012  budget  allocates  significant 
additional resources to implement the Masterplan for Acceleration and Expansion of Indonesia's 

The Government’s Countercyclical Support Measures 

                                                 
8  Debt Sustainability Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

  
6

 

Economic  Development  (MP3EI),  2011–2025.  The  MP3EI  includes  efforts  to  accelerate 
infrastructure  development,  introduce  key  reforms  to  remove  bottlenecks,  and  close  the 
development  gap  between  the  eastern  and  western  regions  of  Indonesia  by  improving 
connectivity  and  developing  six  economic  corridors.  To  address  the  removal  of  infrastructure 
bottlenecks,  the  budget  boosts  capital  increased  by  45.6%  in  2012  from  that  in  2011.  The 
budget  also  increases  social  spending,  including  for  the  country’s  flagship  poverty  reduction 
programs  such  as  Program  Nasional  Pemberdayaan  Masyarakat  (Community  Empowerment 
Program).  To anticipate the impacts of weaker global growth and increasing oil prices, in March 
2012 the Parliament passed a revision to the 2012 budget, widening the fiscal deficit to 2.2% of 
GDP from an originally planned 1.5%. The revised budget contains three key components: (i) a 
provision  to  increase  the  administered  domestic  fuel  price  once  the  6-month  average  of  the 
Indonesian crude oil price exceeds $120.80; (ii) an additional $2.8 billion of social spending to 
compensate  Indonesians  for  inflation  resulting  from  any  fuel  price  rise,  comprising  direct  cash 
transfers  and  rural  infrastructure  investment;  and  (iii)  conditional  cash  transfers.  The  revised 
budget also allocates an additional $1.9 billion in capital spending. 
 
Strengthening  public  finance  management.  The  effectiveness  of  the  government’s 
18. 
fiscal stimulus depends on better budget execution. Execution of investment projects continues 
to  be  a  challenge.  The  key  agencies  implementing  infrastructure  spending  (the  ministries  of 
Public Works and Transportation) have relatively low absorptive capacity rates, causing delays 
in  disbursements  and  procurement  that  could  undermine  the  government’s  stimulus  package. 
Therefore, measures to accelerate disbursement of capital spending will form an important part 
of  the  government’s  efforts  to  stimulate  domestic  demand.  Attempts  by  the  government  to 
remove obstacles to more efficient budget execution since 2010 have had mixed success, to a 
large extent because of the relatively old regulation governing budget execution. To be able to 
use  fiscal  policy  to  stimulate  domestic  demand  in  case  of  a  crisis,  projects  need  to  be 
implemented  in  a  swift  manner.  To  rectify  the  constraints  above,  the  government  recently 
established  a  task  force  to  accelerate  budget  disbursements,  led  and  coordinated  by  the  Unit 
Kerja  Presiden  Bidang  Pengawasan  dan  Pengendalian  Pembangunan  (President’s  Delivery 
Unit  for  Development  Monitoring  and  Oversight).  The  government  is  now  revising  related 
regulations to improve budget execution. 
 
Better  poverty  targeting  approach.  To  further  accelerate  the  pace  of  poverty 
19. 
reduction, the government is pursuing key reforms of its national poverty reduction programs to 
achieve  the  target  set  in  Rencana  Pembangunan  Jangka  Menengah  Nasional  (National 
Medium-Term  Development  Plan),  2010–2014.  These  efforts  include  establishing  a  national 
targeting  system  to  ensure  that  program  benefits  accurately  reach  the  poor  and  vulnerable 
households.  Currently,  household  poverty  reduction  programs  use  different 
targeting 
approaches  and  rely  on  separate  recipient  databases.  This  leads  to  duplication  of  efforts  and 
inconsistency  in  application,  and  dampens  program  impact.  The  national  targeting  system  will 
construct  and  maintain  a  unified  targeting  database,  to  be  used  by  all  programs,  on  potential 
beneficiaries  drawn  from  the  poorest  40%  of  the  population.  The  single  source  of  quality-
controlled  data  will  help  improve  programs'  targeting  outcomes  and  boost  synergies  between 
programs. A unified database also reduces fraud, corruption, and duplication, while simplifying 
program exit strategies. 
 
E. 
 
Economic  stimulus  effects.  While  domestic  consumption  provides  a  good  base  for 
20. 
stable  growth,  a  supportive  external  environment  is  essential  for  stronger  growth  dynamics 
through  exports  and  investment.  In  2011,  net  exports  contributed  1.5 percentage  points  to  the 

Economic Impacts of the Government’s Countercyclical Measures 

 

  
 

7

 

Impact, Output, Scope, and Coverage  

country’s  economic  growth.  Dynamic  export  growth  also  stimulated  a  large  inflow  of  FDI. 
Therefore, if export growth stagnated, economic growth could be significantly reduced by about 
1  percentage  point–1.5  percentage  points.  The  fiscal  stimulus  package  is  required  to  mitigate 
the potential impact of an export slowdown. Assuming that the average  multiplier effect of the 
government’s fiscal stimulus is close to one, the ideal size of the fiscal stimulus should be close 
to 1%–1.5% of GDP. In the context of Indonesia, this can be achieved through a combination of 
increased spending and better budget execution.  In 2010–2011, the government was not able 
to optimally use the available fiscal space, ranging from 0.5% to 1% of GDP. Past experience 
also suggests that an economic growth rate of above 6% per annum is necessary to ensure a 
sustained  reduction  in  unemployment  and  poverty.    A  stronger  growth  in  2011  reduced  the 
number of people below the poverty line by 1.1 million (footnote 4). In addition, it led to a higher 
quality of job creation.  
 
F. 
 
21 
The impact of the facility will be to sustain the government’s capacity to achieve pro-poor 
economic  growth  over  the  medium  term.  The  outcome  will  be  sustained  priority  government 
spending  and  higher  domestic  demand.  This  will  in  turn  generate  jobs  and  sustain  poverty 
reduction during a period of high global economic uncertainties. 
 
Financing  plan  and  ADB  risk-bearing  capacity.  The  government  has  requested  a 
22. 
loan of $500,000,000 under the facility from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be 
determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending 
facility  plus  200  bps9 and  a  rebate  or  surcharge  reflecting  the  cost  of  funds;  a  5-year  term, 
including a grace period of 3 years; annuity-style repayment option; commitment charge of 75 
bps on the undisbursed loan balance; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially 
in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board. Based on 
these loan terms and repayment option, the average loan maturity is 4.28 years and there is no 
maturity premium payable to ADB. The government has provided ADB with: (i) the reasons for 
its  decision  to  borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility  based  on  these  terms  and 
conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not 
made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
  
The facility loan is in line with ADB’s long term capital adequacy framework.10 The facility 
23. 
loan, if approved, is expected to have a positive implication on ADB's medium to long term risk 
bearing capacity, based on its term of 5 years and market-based interest spread of 200 basis 
points.  For  example,  an  immediate  disbursement  of  $500  million  could  result  in  an  improved 
equity-to-loan ratio of about 3–4 basis point by 2017 when the loan is fully repaid. 
 
24. 
The  government  is  committed  to  first  meeting  its  financing  need  from  market  sources 
and  will  back  up  its  intention  with  confidence-boosting  policy  measures.  In  this  context,  the 
government has placed the task of reassuring financial markets at the top of its crisis response 
agenda. The government recognizes that maintaining financial market confidence is critical to its 
ability  to  mobilize  the  necessary  resources  to  finance  public  expenditures  and  to  the  overall 
economic  prospects  of  the  country.  Therefore,  under  both  the  baseline and  the  slower  growth 
scenarios  (para.  7),  the  government  will  maintain  macroeconomic  stability  and  implement 
confidence-boosting  policy  measures  such  as  the  bond  stabilization  framework  and  other 
macroprudential  measures  to  ensure  financial  market  confidence.  Under  these  two  scenarios,

be  withdrawn.  However,  the  package  adds  to  market  confidence  since  the  availability  of

25. 
The  government  will  access  the  facility  only  under  the  crisis  scenario.  The  financing 
plan,  issued  as  a  Directorate  General  of  Debt  Management  (DGDM)  Decree  No.  21/PU/2012 
issued in April 2012, sets out: (i) the government’s financing targets for fiscal year 2012, (ii) the 
terms and circumstances under which the government will drawdown the facility and the related 
support from other development partners to meet its financing shortfall, and (iii) the terms under 
which the financing plan may be rolled over and reissued for fiscal year 2013. The government 
and  development  partners  will  constantly  review 
these  parameters  using  governance 
arrangements  in  the  financing  plan  that  allow  the  government  and  development  partners  to 
assess whether disbursement from the loans is required in line with the government’s financing 
plan.  
 
G. 
 
26. 
The  DGDM  will  be  the  executing  agency  to  coordinate,  monitor,  and  evaluate  the 
implementation  of  the  financing  plan  and  the  government’s  countercyclical  fiscal  stimulus 
programs  supported  by  the  loan.  DGDM  will  convene  a  quarterly  meeting  attended  by 
representatives from the government and development partners to oversee the implementation 
of the financing plan. The monitoring of the fiscal stimulus programs will utilize the government 
system.  For  example,  for  infrastructure  spending,  the  government  has  also  assigned  the 
President’s Delivery Unit for Development Monitoring and Oversight to monitor and coordinate 
its implementation. The government and development partners will meet each quarter to review 
(i)  macroeconomic  conditions,  (ii) implementation  of  the  financing  plan,  (iii)  the  government’s 
countercyclical programs, and (iv) the government’s financing shortfall. The coverage period for 
the facility is from 1 July 2012 to 31 December 2013. The loan of $500 million is to be disbursed 
when  the  government  (i)  has  met  the  drawdown  criteria  set  out  in  the  government’s  financing 
plan; and (ii) maintain sound macroeconomic management.11 The proceeds of the loan will be 
disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement 
Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans.12 
 
27. 
Under the financing plan, drawdown of the facility would be linked to Indonesia’s access 
to  market  financing  and  will  only  occur  if  (a) the  financing  target  has  not  been  met  and  (b) 
government bond yields are above a predetermined level. The financing plan reflects that, if a 
drawdown  is  warranted  as  described  above,  the  government  will  request  support  from 
development partners to meet its financing needs. The loan proceeds will be used to finance the 
cost  (excluding  local  taxes  and  duties)  of  items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member 
countries, excluding ineligible items.13 The full amount of the loan is not required at once. The 
government has articulated a phased drawdown structure in line with its financing targets in its 
financing  plan.  Disbursement  would  be  made  once  every  quarter  and  only  if  the  specified 
financing target has not been met given the specified thresholds for interest rates.

Governance 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

9

 

The government has made considerable progress in the legal and regulatory framework 
28. 
for public financial management.  Since the enactment of the laws on State Finance, on State 
Treasury, and on State Audit in 2003–2004, most of the regulations underpinning the laws have 
been promulgated. Initial findings from the 2011 public expenditure and financial accountability 
repeat assessment show a marked improvement in budget controls and reporting. In 2009, the 
government achieved its first qualified audit opinion from the External Audit Agency, with around 
40%  of  ministries  and  agencies  achieving  unqualified  opinions.  ADB  is  building  on  this 
momentum  with  continuing  support  to  improve  technical  capacity  and  controls.  Building  on 
previous  programs,  ADB  technical  assistance  for  Strengthening  National  Public  Procurement 
Processes 14  has  been  committed  to  improve  the  transparency  and  efficiency  in  public 
procurement processes. With the government’s continuing commitment to reducing corruption, 
the Transparency International’s corruption perception index for Indonesia has improved to 3.0 
in 2011, from 2.8 in 2010.15 
 
B. 

Poverty and Social 

The  facility  supports  the  government’s  efforts  to  sustain  critical  public  expenditures  on 
29. 
infrastructure,  and  poverty  alleviation  and  social  protection.  In  addition,  the  countercyclical 
support  includes  a  component  to  accelerate  budget  execution  for  infrastructure  development, 
which will have a positive impact on the poor, since the government would then be able to more 
effectively  use  fiscal  policy  to  stimulate  demand  and  therefore  dampen  the  negative  impact  of 
any external shocks. The facility will also support the government’s crisis response program to 
help  the  poor  and  vulnerable  during  a  crisis  by  improving  monitoring,  data  collection,  and  the 
targeting system. These actions are also expected to improve the ability of the government to 
put in place an emergency assistance plan to assist the poor in a relatively short time.16

Indicators 

ADB Staff Assessment 

The Indonesian economy has been adversely affected by the eurozone sovereign debt crisis 
and the economic slowdown in several ways. With increasing reliance on  market financing, 
government  finances  have  been  more  vulnerable  to  the  deteriorating  external  market 
conditions  and  increased  market  volatility.  The  economy  has  been  affected  by  declining 
export  growth  since  the  last  quarter  of  2011.  Although  the  economy  is  still  resilient,  the 
downside  risks  to  growth  have  increased  significantly.  With  an  uncertain  and  potentially 
weaker  external  environment,  there  is  a  compelling  need  to  stimulate  domestic  demand  in 
order to continue the current pace of poverty reduction.  
Economic  growth  accelerated  further  despite  weakening  external  demand  from  the 
deteriorating sovereign debt situation. GDP growth edged up to 6.5% year-on-year in 2011, 
from  6.2%  in  2010  supported  by  sustained  private  consumption  and  stronger  investment. 
Export  slowdown  in  Q4  was  compensated  by  increased  government’s  spending  to  prevent 
growth  from  declining.  However,  the  downside  risks  for  future  growth  have  increased 
significantly through weakening export growth. 
Export growth declined to 5.1% (year-on-year) Q1 2012 from 30.8% in Q1 2011. Investment 
recorded a negative growth of 2.2% in Q4 2011. 
Remittances declined by 6.4% from $1.2 billion in Q4 2010 to $1.1 billion in Q4 2011. 
To accommodate the fiscal stimulus, the Government increased the budget deficit from 1.2% 
of GDP in 2011 to 1.5% in the 2012 Budget. The Parliament passed a revised 2012 budget 
with a larger deficit of 2.2% in March 2012. 
Tax revenue collection  was up by 0.7% of GDP in 2011, largely due to the efforts to widen 
the tax net and improve tax administration.  
Non-residents  sold  a  large  amount  of  government  rupiah  securities  ($4.1  billion)  in 
September  and  October  2011.  Yields  of  government’s  5-year  government  bond  surged  by 
about 120 bps. Yields have gradually declined since the second week of October 2011 due 
to the government’s bond stabilization programs. 
The  Government  is  implementing  a  countercyclical  program  that  focuses  on  (i)  increasing 
infrastructure spending, (ii) improving budget execution, and (iii) scaling up and improving the 
targeting system of the flagship poverty programs. 
The  2012  budget  increases  capital  expenditure  by  33.7%  from  the  2011  levels.  The 
infrastructure spending includes development of airports, ports, mass rapid transport system, 
new  roads  and  hinterland  connections.  The  Government  is  considering  to  include  in  the 
revised budget additional infrastructure spending from the 2011 unspent balance.  
The Government has scaled up its National Community Empowerment Program (PNPM) for 
2012. In response to the current crisis, the government is establishing of a National Targeting 
System  to  ensure  that  program  benefits  more  accurately  reach  poor  and  vulnerable 
households.

ADB Staff Assessment 

The  Government  has  maintained  sound  macroeconomic  management  and  introduced  swift 
measures  to  mitigate  the  impact  of  the  eurozone  crisis  and  the  global  economic  slowdown. 
This involved taking a number of preemptive measures aimed at maintaining the stability of 
the domestic bond market and introducing macroprudential measures to manage speculative 
capital  inflows  The  Government  also  maintains  flexibility  in  the  2012 budget  to  facilitate  the 
need to stimulate domestic demand while easing monetary policy appropriately to respond to 
weakening growth prospects. 
After  the  inflation  downward  trend  firmed  up  in  the  second  half  of  2011,  Bank  Indonesia 
started an easing cycle in October 2011 by cutting its policy rate by 100bps through February 
2012. The cuts  were also taken to frontload some adjustment measures in response to the 
expected  global  economic  slowdown.  Year-on-year  inflation  declined  to  3.8%  in  December 
2011.  The  deceleration  trend  was  reversed  in  March  and  the  year-on-year  inflation  rate 
edged up to 4.5% in April.  
The  Government  introduced  the  Bond  Stabilization  Framework  (BSF).  The  BSF  includes  a 
number of actions to stabilize the domestic bond market in the event of market turbulence by 
buying  back  in  the  secondary  market  using:  funds  from  the  state  budget;  fund-pooling  by 
state-owned enterprises; accumulated budget surplus, and internal reserves accumulated by 
Bank  Indonesia.  Under  the  BSF,  the  Government,  in  coordination  with  Bank  Indonesia, 
bought back a significant amount of government bonds in the secondary market to stabilize 
bond  yields.  Bank  Indonesia  also  implemented  a  number  of  macroprudential  measures  to 
reduce short-term and speculative capital inflows and mitigate the risks of sudden reversals. 
Public  debt  is  sustainable.  Indonesia’s  debt-to-GDP  ratio  has  fallen  steadily  in  the  last 
decade,  including  against  the  backdrop  of  the  2008-09  global  financial  crisis.  The 
countercyclical spending program is not expected to adversely affect debt sustainability as a 
large proportion of the 2012 budget stimulus is devoted to additional infrastructure spending, 
which will improve the capacity to of the economy to grow higher in the medium term. Even 
with a shock of a 10% increase in government debt liability in 2012, the debt ratio is projected 
to return to the current level by 2016. 
The  Government  has  an  aggressive  PFM  reform  program  supported  by  a  number  of 
development partners including through ADB’s earlier Development Policy Support Program 
series. Key reforms include strengthening the budgetary process, budget transparency, and 
civil service reforms.  
The external balance position is strong. Gross international reserves at the end of April 2012 
were $116.4 billion, sufficient for 6.4 months of imports and servicing of official external debt.
